senses.de: To commit firmly to something, making it difficult to change or reverse.
senses.ex: We've locked into a five-year contract with our supplier.
cl: lock into a course of action

Tips.title: Commitments and Agreements
Tips.description: Use 'lock into' when discussing binding agreements or decisions that are hard to change.
Tips.example: They locked into a fixed-rate mortgage to avoid fluctuating interest rates.

Tips.title: Fixed Plans or Strategies
Tips.description: Use it to describe adhering to a specific plan or strategy.
Tips.example: The team locked into their game plan and executed it flawlessly.

senses.de: To become firmly fixed or established in a particular position or state.

Tips.title: Physical Mechanisms
Tips.description: Use 'lock into' to describe how parts of a mechanism fit securely together.
Tips.example: The safety latch locked into place, preventing accidental opening.

commit to.wordDefinition: 'Commit to' implies a voluntary pledge or promise, while 'lock into' emphasizes the binding nature and difficulty of changing the decision.

fix on.wordDefinition: 'Fix on' suggests focusing attention or deciding upon something, whereas 'lock into' adds the element of being firmly committed and unable to easily change course.

settle on.wordDefinition: 'Settle on' means to choose or decide upon something after consideration, while 'lock into' highlights the finality and fixed nature of the decision.
